prompt:
Patient: 4-year-old with fever, decreased appetite, cough for 3 days.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 4-year-old presents with 3-day history of fever, cough, decreased appetite. No vomiting or diarrhea. Mild irritability noted.
Physical Exam: Temp 101.2°F, lungs clear, pharyngeal erythema, no rash.
Assessment: Viral upper respiratory infection.
Plan: Supportive care, fluids, antipyretics as needed, return if symptoms worsen.

prompt:
Patient: 7-year-old with persistent headache and mild photophobia.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 7-year-old with 3-day headache, mild photophobia, no nausea or vomiting.
Physical Exam: Vitals normal, neurologic exam normal.
Assessment: Tension-type headache.
Plan: Supportive care, hydration, OTC analgesics, follow-up if worsens.

prompt:
Patient: 2-year-old with runny nose and mild cough.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 2-year-old with 2-day runny nose, mild cough, no fever.
Physical Exam: Vitals normal, lungs clear.
Assessment: Common cold.
Plan: Supportive care, monitor for fever, fluids, follow-up if symptoms worsen.

prompt:
Patient: 5-year-old with abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea for 1 day.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 5-year-old with 1-day history of abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. No blood in stool.
Physical Exam: Abdomen soft, mild tenderness, vitals stable.
Assessment: Viral gastroenteritis.
Plan: Hydration, supportive care, monitor for dehydration, return if worsens.

prompt:
Patient: 6-year-old with rash on arms and legs, mild itching.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 6-year-old with 1-day rash on extremities, mild itching, no fever.
Physical Exam: Erythematous maculopapular rash on arms and legs, no other findings.
Assessment: Likely allergic reaction.
Plan: Antihistamine, avoid irritants, monitor for spread or fever, follow-up if worsens.

prompt:
Patient: 3-year-old with ear pain and mild fever.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 3-year-old with 2-day right ear pain, mild fever 100.8°F, no discharge.
Physical Exam: TM erythematous, mild bulging, lungs clear.
Assessment: Acute otitis media.
Plan: Analgesics, monitor, antibiotics if worsens, follow-up in 48 hours.

prompt:
Patient: 8-year-old with sore throat and cough.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 8-year-old with 3-day sore throat, mild cough, no fever.
Physical Exam: Pharyngeal erythema, tonsils not enlarged, lungs clear.
Assessment: Viral pharyngitis.
Plan: Supportive care, fluids, OTC analgesics, return if fever develops.

prompt:
Patient: 5-year-old with mild wheezing after playing outside.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 5-year-old with intermittent wheezing during outdoor play, no fever.
Physical Exam: Wheezing on auscultation, lungs otherwise clear.
Assessment: Mild exercise-induced asthma.
Plan: Short-acting inhaler as needed, monitor, follow-up with pulmonology if persistent.

prompt:
Patient: 6-year-old with constipation for 1 week.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 6-year-old with 1-week history of infrequent bowel movements, hard stools.
Physical Exam: Abdomen soft, mild tenderness in lower quadrants.
Assessment: Functional constipation.
Plan: Increase fluids and fiber, stool softeners as needed, monitor bowel habits.

prompt:
Patient: 7-year-old with mild dehydration after 2 days of diarrhea.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 7-year-old with 2-day diarrhea, decreased oral intake, mild dehydration signs.
Physical Exam: Dry mucous membranes, capillary refill <2s, vitals stable.
Assessment: Mild dehydration secondary to viral gastroenteritis.
Plan: Oral rehydration solution, monitor hydration, return if worsens.

prompt:
Patient: 4-year-old with mild asthma exacerbation.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 4-year-old with increased coughing and wheezing for 1 day, uses inhaler twice daily.
Physical Exam: Mild wheezing, lungs otherwise clear.
Assessment: Mild asthma exacerbation.
Plan: Continue inhaler, monitor symptoms, follow-up in clinic.

prompt:
Patient: 5-year-old with conjunctivitis.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 5-year-old with red eyes, mild discharge, no pain, no vision changes.
Physical Exam: Conjunctival injection, mild watery discharge, pupils reactive.
Assessment: Viral conjunctivitis.
Plan: Supportive care, hand hygiene, monitor for bacterial signs.

prompt:
Patient: 6-year-old with minor laceration on hand.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 6-year-old sustained minor cut on left hand while playing, no foreign body.
Physical Exam: 2 cm superficial laceration, clean, minimal bleeding.
Assessment: Superficial laceration.
Plan: Clean wound, apply bandage, tetanus status up to date, monitor for infection.

prompt:
Patient: 3-year-old with mild fever and irritability.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 3-year-old with fever 100.6°F for 1 day, irritable, no rash.
Physical Exam: Vitals stable, lungs clear, tympanic membranes normal.
Assessment: Likely viral infection.
Plan: Supportive care, fluids, antipyretics as needed.

prompt:
Patient: 8-year-old with mild ankle sprain.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 8-year-old twisted right ankle while running, mild pain, no bruising.
Physical Exam: Mild swelling, tenderness over lateral ligaments, no deformity.
Assessment: Mild ankle sprain.
Plan: Rest, ice, compression, elevation, monitor for worsening.

prompt:
Patient: 7-year-old with seasonal allergies.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 7-year-old with sneezing, watery eyes, nasal congestion during spring.
Physical Exam: Clear lungs, pale nasal mucosa.
Assessment: Seasonal allergic rhinitis.
Plan: Antihistamines as needed, avoid triggers, monitor symptoms.

prompt:
Patient: 6-year-old with mild dehydration after vomiting.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 6-year-old with 1-day vomiting, decreased oral intake.
Physical Exam: Dry mucous membranes, vitals stable.
Assessment: Mild dehydration secondary to viral illness.
Plan: Oral rehydration, monitor, return if worsens.

prompt:
Patient: 5-year-old with mild ear infection.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 5-year-old with right ear pain for 1 day, mild fever 100.5°F.
Physical Exam: TM erythematous, mild bulging.
Assessment: Acute otitis media.
Plan: Analgesics, monitor, antibiotics if worsens.

prompt:
Patient: 4-year-old with mild asthma flare.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 4-year-old with increased wheezing and coughing for 1 day.
Physical Exam: Mild wheezing, lungs otherwise clear.
Assessment: Mild asthma exacerbation.
Plan: Use inhaler as needed, monitor, follow-up if symptoms persist.

prompt:
Patient: 3-year-old with diaper rash.

Summarize:
completion:
History: 3-year-old with red, irritated skin in diaper area, no fever.
Physical Exam: Erythematous rash in diaper area, no pustules.
Assessment: Diaper dermatitis.
Plan: Keep area clean and dry, barrier cream, monitor for infection.
